title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: Can portable headsets peer into the minds of hunter-gatherers and other understudied populations?
items.description: <cite>Science</cite> chats with health economist Shailender Swaminathan about how compact EEGs could reveal the impact of culture and environment on the brain

items.title: Employees’ protests against Trump science policies spread to NSF
items.description: Letter to key House Democrat follows declarations by scientists at NIH, EPA, and NASA

items.title: Watch an earthquake split a hillside in two
items.description: Footage of massive Myanmar temblor provides the first video evidence of earthquake ruptures

items.title: Engineers transform dental floss into needle-free vaccine
items.description: New method places inactivated viruses directly into mice’s gums

items.title: Octopuses fall for the ‘rubber arm’ illusion, just like us
items.description: Experiment shows octopuses feel body ownership, a trait previously seen only in mammals

items.title: Insect X-Men: Helmets help these odd bugs sense electric fields
items.description: Ability may help treehoppers distinguish friend from foe

items.title: Storing hydrogen in oil-like liquid could allow easy transport in trucks and ships
items.description: Cheap catalyst could improve global access to costly green fuel

items.title: Betelgeuse’s long-predicted stellar companion may have been found at last
items.description: Small star could crash into red supergiant in the next 10,000 years

items.title: Fearful of AI-generated grant proposals, NIH limits scientists to six applications per year
items.description: Some critics of the new policy say the cap could hinder researchers in need of funding

items.title: U.S. research community says new indirect cost model is still too complicated
items.description: Proposed changes to avert huge cuts in reimbursement get pushback at town hall
